author: sunce86.
content:
Just to clarify the internal implementation. You probably assumed that best_transaction contains all transactions in the pool but it doesn't. It actually contains only one best transaction from each sender. For example, if you have sender A with transactions A1, A2, A3 and sender B with transactions B1, B2, totaling 5 transactions in tx pool, then best_transactions contains only two of them, A1,B1. Then, if you want to print the sorted list of txs in tx pool, you would take the best one from best_transactions (for example B1), remove it from best_transactions, and then insert the next best transaction from that same sender(B) (if exist) into best_transactions (B2). Now it contains A1,B2.  You would iterate like this until no more txs.
So, based on this, it is clear why OE need the same structure to handle the worst transactions in a same manner.

author: sunce86.
content: "It actually contains only one best transaction from each sender." - actually not the best, but the transaction with the smallest nonce. We need to respect the transaction nonce from a single sender, and process them in order, regardless if maybe the transaction with the highest nonce has also the highest gas price. That would not be possible to respect if we would have only one structure best_transaction with all the thx from all senders.
